title: 107_hr2313
content: The Act may be cited as the "Crane Tithe Tax Act of 2001" and repeals the taxation of corporations. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 repeals various taxes related to corporations, including corporate income tax, alternative minimum tax for corporations, unrelated business income tax, accumulated earnings tax, personal holding company tax, alternative tax for certain mutual savings banks, tax on life insurance companies, tax on certain mutual insurance companies, tax on certain other insurance companies, and tax on regulated investment companies. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 repeals taxes on various corporations, including regulated investment companies, real estate investment trusts, and income of foreign corporations connected with United States business. SEC. 3. 10 PERCENT INCOME TAX RATE FOR INDIVIDUALS. Amends Section 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to impose a 10 percent income tax rate for individuals. The tax rate for individuals is 10 percent of earned income over the exemption amount, which is $10,000 adjusted for inflation. The term 'earned income' is defined as income exceeding the exemption amount, subject to a 10 percent tax rate. The Consumer Price Index is used to calculate any necessary adjustments. The term 'earned income' includes wages, self-employment earnings, and certain dividends. It excludes pensions, annuities, and discretionary tips. The cost of fringe benefits included as earned income is the employer's expense. SEC. 4 grants amnesty for all prior tax liability before January 1, 2000, with exceptions for amounts paid before the enactment of the Act and taxes related to illegal activities. SEC. 5 repeals special deductions, credits, and income exclusions for individuals. Chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to remove specific exclusions, deductions, and credits related to individual income tax liability. Estate and gift taxes under Subtitle B of the Code are repealed. Effective dates are specified in Section 7. The amendments made by this Act apply to taxable years starting after enactment. The repeal of estate and gift taxes applies to estates of decedents dying after enactment. The Secretary of the Treasury must submit technical changes to the Internal Revenue Code within 90 days of enactment.
